definition: point/dot/drop/speck/o'clock/point (in space or time)/to draw a dot/to check on a list/to choose/to order (food in a restaurant)/to touch briefly/to hint/to light/to ignite/to pour a liquid drop by drop/(old) one fifth of a two-hour watch 更[geng1]/dot stroke in Chinese characters/classifier for items

sentences.english: This means that there are two big unknowns about the robot.
sentences.chinese: 這意味着這款機器人存在着兩大疑點。

sentences.english: There are still a few questionable points in the case.
sentences.chinese: 這個案件還有幾個疑點。

sentences.english: Members boot any doubts as to not miss the target and immediately issued instructions to open packages.
sentences.chinese: 開機員以不放過任何疑點爲目標，立即下達開包指令。

sentences.english: and also he set down every sensible doubtful point.
sentences.chinese: 並且他還記下每一條明顯的疑點。

sentences.english: This paper clarified some doubtful and difficult points in COQ management.
sentences.chinese: 本文澄清了質量成本管理過程中的一些疑點和難點。

sentences.english: This difference, together with differences in instance counts, is the key to discovering leak suspects.
sentences.chinese: 此差別與實例計數的差別是發現泄漏疑點的關鍵。

definition: the rise and fall of the terrain (idiom)/(fig.) the whole sequence of events/causes and effects
to contend on strong grounds/to argue strongly for what is right
fuse (for explosives)/(fig.) proximate cause/the last straw
lit. spider's thread and horse track/tiny hints (of a secret)/traces/clue
to examine a wound or injury (typically for forensic purposes)
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
to oppose each other with equal harshness (idiom); tit for tat/measure for measure
